Award.AwardTitle: HOx Radical Chemistry in Forest Environments: Measurements and Characterization of Instrument Interferences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research focuses on the measurement of several of the most important chemical compounds in the atmosphere, the hydroxyl (OH) and hydroperoxy (HO2) radicals. These compounds are important in atmospheric chemistry because they control the lifetimes of many trace gases important to issue of climate change and they can greatly influence air quality. Scientists have found many disagreements between the measurements of these compounds by a variety of methods and by the models that predict their concentrations. This work will investigate the nature of these disagreements and focus on improving the measurement of these compounds, thereby improving the ability of models to better predict climate and air quality.

Although there has been reasonable agreement between measured and modeled HOx (OH + HO2) concentrations in urban areas, measurements in forested environments characterized by high mixing ratios of biogenic volatile organic compounds have shown major discrepancies with modeling results. This research includes optimization of the LP/LIF-FAGE instrument, laboratory kinetics experiments, informal instrument intercomparison studies, and investigations of instrument performance in a variety of forest environments under changing environmental conditions. The forest measurements will take place at several locations including the Indiana University Research and Teaching Preserve field lab near the Bloomington campus, the PROPHET (Program for Research on Oxidants: PHotochemistry, Emissions and Transport) site in northern Michigan, as well as at the nearby Forest Accelerated Succession Experiment site. This work will support several graduate students and minority student will be especially encouraged to participate in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The hydroxyl radical (OH) and the hydroperoxy (HO2) radical play a central role in the chemistry of the atmosphere. In addition to controlling the lifetimes of many gases important to issues of global climate change, OH radical reactions initiate the oxidation of carbon monoxide and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) which in the presence of nitrogen oxides (NOx) can lead to the production of ozone and secondary aerosols in the atmosphere, the primary components of photochemical smog. Recent measurements of OH and HO2 radicals have revealed serious discrepancies with model predictions, especially in forested environments with high emissions of biogenic VOCs. These results suggest that either our understanding of the chemistry of biogenic VOCs is incomplete or that there are unknown interferences associated with measurements of these radicals in the atmosphere.

Intellectual Merit:  The inability of current models of atmospheric chemistry to explain measured concentrations of OH radicals in forested environments has important implications to current issues of air quality and climate change, as it questions our understanding of the contribution of biogenic emissions to the production of ozone and aerosols in the atmosphere as well as our ability to predict how well the atmosphere will be able to remove methane and other greenhouse gases in the future. However, recent studies have suggested that some instruments that measure OH in the atmosphere may suffer from unknown interferences, which could explain the discrepancies with model predictions.

Laboratory studies were conducted in order to determine whether biogenic VOCs and their oxidation products could produce an interference in measurements of OH and HO2 using the Indiana University Laser-Induced Fluorescence - Fluorescence Assay by Gas Expansion (LIF-FAGE) technique. It was found that measurements of OH by this instrument is susceptible to an interference from the reaction of ozone with several biogenic VOCs. However, extrapolating these results to ambient conditions suggested that this interference would be below the detection limit of the instrument. It was also found that measurements of HO2 are also susceptible to an interference from the products of biogenic VOC oxidation.

During the summer of 2015, measurements of OH and HO2 were conducted in a forested environment near the Indiana University, Bloomington campus. Using a scavenger technique, a significant interference was observed in contrast to that expected from the laboratory studies. The interference resulted in apparent OH concentrations that were significantly greater than model predictions, similar to that observed by other instruments. However, subtracting the interference resulted in OH concentrations that were in better agreement with model predictions. Similarly, measurements of HO2 were also in good agreement with model predictions when instrumental interferences were taken into account.

During the summer of 2016, measurements of OH and HO2 were conducted in a northern Michigan forest as part of the Program for Research on Oxidants: Photochemistry, Emissions, and Transport - Atmospheric Measurements of Oxidants in Summer (PROPHET-AMOS) campaign. Similar to the previous campaign, measurements of OH concentrations were in good agreement with model predictions. No unknown interferences were observed at this site where biogenic VOC concentrations were lower. However the measured HO2 concentrations were significantly lower than model predictions, in contrast to the previous campaign. Because the concentrations of NOx were much lower, these results question either our understanding of the chemistry of these radicals under low NOx conditions, or the accuracy of the measurements.

To help determine whether these measurements are accurate, an informal intercomparison of OH and HO2 measurements was conducted during the summer of 2017. In addition to the LIF-FAGE instrument, two Chemical Ionization Mass Spectrometer (CIMS) instruments also measured OH and HO2 concentrations. The results from the two instruments agreed to within their respective uncertainties, suggesting that OH and HO2 measurements by the different techniques are accurately refecting the ambient concentrations.

Broader Impacts: These results suggest that previous measurements of OH in forest environments may have suffered from interferences, and that future measurements using the LIF-FAGE technique should employ techniques to measure and account for potential interferences. When interferences were measured and taken into account, the resulting OH concentrations were in good agreement with model predictions, suggesting that our understanding of the chemistry of biogenic VOCs is better than previously believed. However, even after taking interferences into account, measurements of HO2 were sometimes found to agree with model predictions, and sometimes found to be significantly lower, especially in clean air forested environments with very low concentrations of NOx. This overestimation of HO2 radical concentrations has important implications on our ability to predict the rate of ozone and aerosol production in the atmosphere, and whether current models can predict the future composition of the atmosphere. Additional measurements are needed to confirm these results and to determine whether these measurements are characteristic of other forest environments around the world.
